issue.title: blocks behind toolbox while dragging to delete

labels.name: issue: bug
labels.description: Describes why the code or behaviour is wrong

issue.body:
### Check for duplicates

- [X] I have searched for similar issues before opening a new one.

### Description

Dragging a blocklyDraggable element onto a blocklyToolboxDiv element will be obstructed by blocklyToolboxDiv, making it impossible to elevate the blocklyDraggable element level. Originally, raising the blocklyBlockDragSurface element level was sufficient. How can we solve this problem?

blocklyDraggable元素拖拽到blocklyToolboxDiv元素会被blocklyToolboxDiv遮挡，无法提升blocklyDraggable元素层级，原来通过提升blocklyBlockDragSurface元素层级即可，如何解决这个问题？

### Reproduction steps

Drag building blocks to toolbox


### Stack trace

_No response_

### Screenshots

![1691069485540](https://github.com/google/blockly/assets/8003658/a9f83fdb-8742-4204-a299-a48ed158846f)


### Browsers

Chrome desktop

comment.body:
Hi @maribethb,
After upgrading to v10.2.2, we still have this issue on our app, however trying to reproduce this on the playground again:
both here:
https://blockly-demo.appspot.com/static/tests/playgrounds/advanced_playground.html#debugEnabled=false
and
https://blockly-demo.appspot.com/static/tests/playground.html
They seem to be working... is the playground using the latest version too (v10.2.2 as of this writing)?

issue.title: Modifying the structure of a block does not trigger widgets to be repositioned

labels.name: issue: bug
labels.description: Describes why the code or behaviour is wrong

issue.body: ### Check for duplicates - [X] I have searched for similar issues before opening a new one. ### Description If a warning icon is added or removed during field editing, the field is not rendered correctly. related to the rendering queue and might be related to #7068 ? ### Reproduction steps 1. Open Block Factory 2. Drag two value input blocks into the inputs input. Notice how they each have a warning now due to conflicting names. 3. Change the name of one of the inputs. The warning disappears, and the underlying block is resized. But the text input html element is now in the wrong place because it did not move when the block was resized. 4. Click outside the field to end editing / close the widget div. 5. Change the name back to `NAME`. The warning reappears, causing the same problem again. ### Stack trace _No response_ ### Screenshots ### Browsers _No response_

commits.message:
fix: widget positioning (#7507)

* chore: delete dead code

* chore: moves location updating into the block

* chore: change dragging to use update component locations

* fix: field widgets not being moved when blocks are editted

* chore: remove unnecessary resizeEditor_ calls

* chore: format

* chore: fix build

* fix: tests

* chore: PR comments

* chore: format

pull_request.title: fix: widget positioning
pull_request.body:
<!--
  - Thanks for submitting code to Blockly!  Please fill out the following as part of
  - your pull request so we can review your code more easily.
  -->

## The basics

<!-- TODO: Verify the following, checking each box with an 'x' between the brackets: [x] -->

- [X] I [validated my changes](https://developers.google.com/blockly/guides/contribute/core#making_and_verifying_a_change)

## The details
### Resolves

<!-- TODO: What Github issue does this resolve? Please include a link. -->
Fixes #7491

### Proposed Changes

<!-- TODO: Describe what this Pull Request does.  Include screenshots if applicable. -->
Reorganizes a bunch of code, and makes it so that fields get `onLocationChange` call backs.

### Reason for Changes

<!--TODO: Explain why these changes should be made.  Include screenshots if applicable. -->
Makes it so that fields can reposition their widgets properly.

### Test Coverage

<!-- TODO: Please create unit tests, and explain here how they cover
           your changes, or tell us how you tested it manually. If
           your changes include browser-specific behaviour, include
           information about the browser and device that you used for
           testing. -->

* Tested that https://github.com/google/blockly/issues/6976 does not reproduce
* Tested that changing the window size properly repositions the div, re: https://github.com/google/blockly/issues/6915
* Tested that #7491  does not reproduce
* Tested that we did not get a significant performance drop by dragging spaghetti blocks, and also typing into the spaghetti blocks. We might have gotten a slight performance dip from splitting up the connection update operations so they're not happening contiguously (the engine can't optimize as much). But all of this code is internal so I can circle back once I've had more time to investigate.

[old-dragging.txt](https://github.com/google/blockly/files/12691991/old-dragging.txt)
[new-dragging.txt](https://github.com/google/blockly/files/12691992/new-dragging.txt)


### Documentation

<!-- TODO: Does any documentation need to be created or updated because of this PR?
  -        If so please explain.
  -->
N/A

### Additional Information

<!-- Anything else we should know? -->
Might want to hold until after release?

## Deprecations

- [ ] TODO

comment.body:
If we trigger a move of the block (the block gets bumped), it triggers `onLocationChange` for all fields, so the field gets bumped that way. If we don't move the block, we still need to reposition the widget because the block might be moving relative to the top-left of the window (even though it's not moving relative to the workspace origin).

Here's what it looks like if I remove the `if (!bumped) this.resizeEditor_();` line:
![Screen recording 2023-10-26 9 31 51 AM](https://github.com/google/blockly/assets/25440652/0ea82227-10f9-435c-9a21-716c579c321b)

You can see that if we do bump, repositioning is handled, but if we don't it is not handled.

issue.title: Crash if a field click deletes a block

labels.name: issue: bug
labels.description: Describes why the code or behaviour is wrong

labels.name: size: small
labels.description: Bugs that can be picked up and completed in 1-3 days

issue.body:
### Check for duplicates

- [ ] I have searched for similar issues before opening a new one.

### Description

If you have a block with a field that deletes the block*, Blockly will crash because the gesture handling code assumes the block continues to exist.

We can fix this in several ways:

1. Move `bringBlockToFront` to the beginning of [`doFieldClick`](https://github.com/google/blockly/blob/9c7c71ad879a62e285d97236e1c6907287463251/core/gesture.ts#L938) (so that it happens before the field has a chance to handle the click)
2. Have `bringBlockToFront` make sure `disposed` is false on the block before calling the `bringToFront` method. This would prevent trying to move a dead/dying block.

### Reproduction steps

1. Add the following block definition to the playground above the `start` call.
```js
Blockly.Blocks['test'] = {
        init: function() {
          this.setStyle('math_blocks');
          this.appendDummyInput()
              .appendField(new Blockly.FieldImage(
                  'media/arrow.png',
                  30,
                  30,
                  'test',
                  function() {
                    this.getSourceBlock().dispose();
                  }
              ));
        }
```
2. Run `npm run start` to start the playground.
3. Load the following JSON into the playground:
```
{
  "blocks": {
    "languageVersion": 0,
    "blocks": [
      {
        "type": "test"
      }
    ]
  }
}
``` 
4. Open the browser.
4. Click the arrow on the block.
5. Observe the error in the console.

### Stack trace

```shell
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'childNodes')
    at BlockSvg$$module$build$src$core$block_svg.bringToFront (block_svg.ts:1227:34)
    at Gesture$$module$build$src$core$gesture.bringBlockToFront_ (gesture.ts:940:25)
    at Gesture$$module$build$src$core$gesture.doFieldClick_ (gesture.ts:880:10)
    at Gesture$$module$build$src$core$gesture.handleUp (gesture.ts:591:14)
    at HTMLDocument.g (browser_events.ts:70:9)
```

### Additional Info

This should also be fixed for icons since, https://github.com/google/blockly/issues/7588 is fixed.

## To Fix

1) Run the reproduction steps above to make sure you can reproduce the issue.
2) Add a check in `bringToFront` that checks if `this.isDeadOrDying()`, and returns early if so.
3) Run the reproduction steps again to make sure the issue doesn't reproduce.

comment.body:
> Great, I'll assign you @Apoorvgarg-creator ! If you have any questions please feel free to ask here. 

Thank you !

issue.title: Crash if a field click deletes a block

labels.name: issue: bug
labels.description: Describes why the code or behaviour is wrong

labels.name: size: small

issue.body:
### Check for duplicates

- [ ] I have searched for similar issues before opening a new one.

### Description

If you have a block with a field that deletes the block*, Blockly will crash because the gesture handling code assumes the block continues to exist.

We can fix this in several ways:

1. Move `bringBlockToFront` to the beginning of [`doFieldClick`](https://github.com/google/blockly/blob/9c7c71ad879a62e285d97236e1c6907287463251/core/gesture.ts#L938) (so that it happens before the field has a chance to handle the click)
2. Have `bringBlockToFront` make sure `disposed` is false on the block before calling the `bringToFront` method. This would prevent trying to move a dead/dying block.

### Reproduction steps

1. Add the following block definition to the playground above the `start` call.
```js
Blockly.Blocks['test'] = {
        init: function() {
          this.setStyle('math_blocks');

```
2. Run `npm run start` to start the playground.
3. Load the following JSON into the playground:

4. Open the browser.
4. Click the arrow on the block.
5. Observe the error in the console.

### Stack trace

```shell
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'childNodes')
    at BlockSvg$$module$build$src$core$block_svg.bringToFront (block_svg.ts:1227:34)
    at Gesture$$module$build$src$core$gesture.bringBlockToFront_ (gesture.ts:940:25)

    at HTMLDocument.g (browser_events.ts:70:9)
```

This should also be fixed for icons since, https://github.com/google/blockly/issues/7588 is fixed.

## To Fix

1) Run the reproduction steps above to make sure you can reproduce the issue.
2) Add a check in `bringToFront` that checks if `this.isDeadOrDying()`, and returns early if so.
3) Run the reproduction steps again to make sure the issue doesn't reproduce.

### Check for duplicates

- [ ] I have searched for similar issues before opening a new one.

### Description

issue.title: Possible bug with comment icons / getCommentText

labels.name: issue: bug
labels.description: Describes why the code or behaviour is wrong

labels.name: issue: triage
labels.description: Issues awaiting triage by a Blockly team member

issue.body:
### Check for duplicates

- [X] I have searched for similar issues before opening a new one.

### Description

We have a report from a user that comments do not always deserialize correctly. Check the stack trace below and [this forum post ](https://groups.google.com/g/blockly/c/Rc5WiS8J1kc)for more information.

In `blockToDom`, we call `getCommentText`, which calls `getIcon`. If `getCommentText` returns something falsey, there's no comment, so we move on. If it has a value, then the block must have a comment, so the block must have a comment icon. However, as shown in the forum post, they're seeing `getIcon` return null after `getCommentText` returns with text. That doesn't make sense upon inspection, because `getCommentText` calls `getIcon`! So I really don't know what's happening here.

We did a bit of debugging and it seemed like sometimes the debugger would stop [here](https://github.com/google/blockly/blob/e45998423975ce50e85cbc83ab5aa27799fcb6e0/core/block.ts#L2238) when calling `getIcon`, which implies that the parameter passed is not an `instanceof IconType`, but also inspecting the value of that parameter seemed like it was indeed an instance of the `IconType` class, so I suspect there may be sourcemaps shenanigans happening making debugging trickier.


I've had a look at the [node-red-contrib-blockly repo](https://github.com/bartbutenaers/node-red-contrib-blockly) and I don't see where they're doing any patching or anything suspicious that would imply this is a problem with their code. So I think this is worth looking into on our side because if we do have a problem with deserializing comments, that would be a problem. 

### Reproduction steps

1. Install node-red
2. Install node-red-contrib-blockly
3. Link blockly to the above library so that we can test local changes to blockly
4. Launch both of the above locally somehow
5. Use a blockly node in node-red
6. When you open the blockly node editor, we get a small playground. There's an expand to full screen button. If you click that, that's when the error is triggered. That may play into things here because presumably that button is loading the xml from the smaller playground. But opening the smaller playground to begin with should also trigger an xml load with the saved node data...
7. I have an email with some test data I don't want to post here, but can share if needed to recreate this.


### Stack trace

```shell
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'getBubbleSize') ( xml.ts:194)
    at blockToDom$$module$build$src$core$xml (xml.ts:194:26)
    at blockToDomWithXY$$module$build$src$core$xml (xml.ts:106:19)
    at Object.workspaceToDom$$module$build$src$core$xml [as workspaceToDom] (xml.ts:54:25)
    at Object.open (<anonymous>:819:51)
    at n (red.min.js?v=:19:44660)
    at red.min.js?v=:19:45794
```


### Screenshots

_No response_

### Browsers

_No response_

comment.body:
Thank you Maribeth!

To outline the issue:
In node-red script tags are used to instantiate and re-instantiate Blockly when configuration change.
The issue is caused by the old Blockly instance creating a workspace that is being serialized by a newer Blockly instance.  This breaks some assumptions in the code, and cause things like `obj instanceof Klass` to fail.

I proposed to the user that they should only load Blockly once in their system.  If that's difficult to do I am proposing a temporary fix by using the same Blockly instance that created the workspace to serialize it to Xml.  I've created a PR for the temporary fix [here](https://github.com/bartbutenaers/node-red-contrib-blockly/pull/116#issue-1962510296).

review.body: Fix the build error then LGTM!

pull_request.title: refactor(generators): Migrate JavaScript generators to TypeScript
pull_request.body:
## The basics

- [X] I [validated my changes](https://developers.google.com/blockly/guides/contribute/core#making_and_verifying_a_change)

## The details
### Resolves

Part of #6828.

### Proposed Changes

Migrate `generators/javascript/*.js` and `generators/javascript.js` to TypeScript.

### Reason for Changes

Finish TS migration.

### Test Coverage

`npm test` passes.  No changes to manual test procedures required.

### Documentation

No changes to documentation yet, as there should be minimal changes to the generated code and no changes to the published typings (because during build we overwrite the generated `.d.ts` files with the ones from `typings/`).

### Additional Information

It may be easier to review this commit-by-commit, as the final format commit make a lot of noisy changes.

issue.title: Make it possible for shadow blocks to mirror the parent colour / style

labels.name: issue: feature request
labels.description: Describes a new feature and why it should be added

labels.name: issue: triage
labels.description: Issues awaiting triage by a Blockly team member

issue.body:
### Check for duplicates

- [X] I have searched for similar issues before opening a new one.

### Problem

This feature request was first filed in https://github.com/google/blockly/issues/7416

See here for a good visual and explanation: https://github.com/google/blockly/issues/7416#issuecomment-1770149878

### Request

The submitted request is to add a constant to the renderer (`BLOCKS_USE_PARENT_STYLE`) that determines whether shadow blocks should match the colors of their parent block.

Note that this would be a workspace-global setting, and not toggleable on a block-specific basis. So you couldn't have text blocks match their parents while special dropdown blocks don't.

### Alternatives considered

I don't think continuously adding settings to themes and renderers to get the to handle complex styling behavior is sustainable. It also breaks separation of responsibility, by forcing renderers to care a bunch about themes.

I think the proper thing to do here is to add more CSS support for themes, so we can leverage the browser's built-in ability to do complex styling. I /think/ we can change themes under the hood to register css instead of setting `fill` attributes. But this needs further investigation (i.e. a design doc). 

### Additional context

_No response_

comment.body: We're on board with the plan of adding whatever support we need to use css instead of themes broadly (that probably deserves its own issue if it doesn't already have one). We didn't discuss how to prioritize this feature request in light of that effort. If we're going to work on the theme/css issue soon then it probably doesn't make sense to add an option for this to the existing theme/renderer system, but we haven't prioritized when we'll work on that.

issue.title: refactor(generators): Migrate JavaScript generators to TypeScript
issue.body:
## The basics

- [X] I [validated my changes](https://developers.google.com/blockly/guides/contribute/core#making_and_verifying_a_change)

## The details
### Resolves

Part of #6828.

### Proposed Changes

Migrate `generators/javascript/*.js` and `generators/javascript.js` to TypeScript.

### Reason for Changes

Finish TS migration.

### Test Coverage

`npm test` passes.  No changes to manual test procedures required.

### Documentation

No changes to documentation yet, as there should be minimal changes to the generated code and no changes to the published typings (because during build we overwrite the generated `.d.ts` files with the ones from `typings/`).

### Additional Information

It may be easier to review this commit-by-commit, as the final format commit make a lot of noisy changes.

comment.body: I believe this is ready for re-review.
I've added a reference to #7326 to #7600.

comment.body: I moved the comment since I thought that worth doing anyway, but it did not result in prettier formatting the argument any differently, and indeed I think it is actually doing the right thing here: there is a single argument to `addReservedWords`, and that argument is in fact split over multiple lines, and the normal rule is that continuation lines should be indented (+4 in Google style, +2 in Prettier style).

comment.body:
As discussed:

My thinking is that it is useful to make these types available so the generator functions can use them for casts (to access the extra properties), but I didn't want to make them public given that they are basically hacks I added to get the library blocks to pass type checking.

My plan remains to try to substantially improve the typing of the block definitions, probably by changing the way the mixin object are defined: Define blocks as subclasses of `Block` (or possibly in some cases subclasses of `BlockSvg`), and then using the `.prototype` object as (or to create) the mixin that is the actual block definition added to `Blockly.Blocks`.  This obviates the need to add a third mechanism for defining blocks to  `core/`, while allowing the types of things within the block definitions to be specified in a more straightforward and understandable way.

Once that's done then I think it would be reasonable to make the resulting type declarations fully public.

issue.title: blocks behind toolbox while dragging to delete

labels.name: issue: bug
labels.description: Describes why the code or behaviour is wrong

issue.body:
### Check for duplicates

- [X] I have searched for similar issues before opening a new one.

### Description

Dragging a blocklyDraggable element onto a blocklyToolboxDiv element will be obstructed by blocklyToolboxDiv, making it impossible to elevate the blocklyDraggable element level. Originally, raising the blocklyBlockDragSurface element level was sufficient. How can we solve this problem?

blocklyDraggable元素拖拽到blocklyToolboxDiv元素会被blocklyToolboxDiv遮挡，无法提升blocklyDraggable元素层级，原来通过提升blocklyBlockDragSurface元素层级即可，如何解决这个问题？

### Reproduction steps

Drag building blocks to toolbox


### Stack trace

_No response_

### Screenshots

![1691069485540](https://github.com/google/blockly/assets/8003658/a9f83fdb-8742-4204-a299-a48ed158846f)


### Browsers

Chrome desktop

comment.body:
> I think adding a drag surface for individual elements is the correct solution, rather than messing with the layering of flyouts and toolboxes.

Since refactoring dragging and layering would be a much bigger project, and this is a user-visible regression, just add the drag surface directly (without changing other parts of layering).
